Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Integration of Psychosocial Care in Orthopaedic Trauma Treatment

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adults with musculoskeletal trauma. Participants were recruited from a trauma centre.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received psychological first aid, psychoeducation, and social support, while the control group received standard orthopaedic care.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To assess the effect of psychosocial care on post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms and functional recovery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in PTSD symptoms measured over 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in PTSD symptoms (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Funding.evidence: Funding: This study received no specific funding.
